quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Whether you are a fan of Palantir or hate everything that they do, they are an important and fast-growing company that is pumping out incredible product leaders, as you'll hear more than any other company in the world. So, it is worth studying and understanding.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A contrarian prompt to study high-performing companies even if you disagree with them, because their talent/operating model can be instructive.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I've never heard an in-depth conversation digging into how they operate, build product, hire, and were able to scale from a primarily services business to a software business.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights a key scaling challenge—transitioning from services to software—and frames the episode around operational and hiring mechanics.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, we go deep into what the heck does Palantir even do, why getting good at managing lots of data is an underappreciated secret to their success, a look at the unique forward deployed engineer role that they innovated, and what other companies can borrow from their insights here.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Calls out an actionable, transferable focus area (data management) and a distinctive role innovation (forward deployed engineer) as sources of advantage.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Nabeel spent almost eight years at Palantir as a forward deployed engineer working on public health projects with US federal agencies, including public health services during the COVID-19 response and applied AI in drug discovery.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete example of the forward-deployed model applied to high-stakes domains (COVID response, drug discovery), grounding the discussion in real deployments.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: WorkOS and Attio
quotes.text: If you're building a SaaS app, at some point, your customers will start asking for enterprise features like SAML authentication and SCIM provisioning.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (WorkOS read)
quotes.context: A practical expectation-setting insight for SaaS builders about the inevitable pull toward enterprise requirements.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: WorkOS and Attio
quotes.text: Warrant's product is based on a groundbreaking authorization system called Zanzibar, which was originally designed for Google to power Google Docs and YouTube.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (WorkOS read)
quotes.context: A concrete example of leveraging a proven, large-scale authorization model originally built for Google products.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: WorkOS and Attio
quotes.text: This enables fast authorization checks at enormous scale while maintaining a flexible model that can be adapted to even the most complex use cases.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (WorkOS read)
quotes.context: A useful mental model for what “good” authorization infrastructure should optimize for: speed, scale, and flexibility.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: WorkOS and Attio
quotes.text: With Attio, AI isn't just a feature, it's the foundation.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Attio read)
quotes.context: A memorable product principle that reframes AI from an add-on to a core architectural approach.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: WorkOS and Attio
quotes.text: Connect your email and calendar and Attio instantly builds a CRM that matches your business model with all of your company's contacts and interactions enriched with actionable insights.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Attio read)
quotes.context: An actionable workflow idea: auto-constructing CRM context from existing communication systems to reduce manual setup.

quotes.topic_title: Why Palantir creates so many founders
quotes.text: I looked at which companies produce the most founders, especially out of their PM team, and Palantir is, by far, number one. 30% of PMs that leave Palantir start a company. And number two is 18% and that's Intercom.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A striking benchmark that quantifies Palantir’s outsized founder output relative to other top companies.

quotes.topic_title: Why Palantir creates so many founders
quotes.text: So, that stat, I looked at which companies PMs that leave get immediately promoted in their next role, Palantir is number one of all companies in the world.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Suggests Palantir PM experience translates unusually well into higher-level roles elsewhere, implying strong training or selection.

quotes.topic_title: Why Palantir creates so many founders
quotes.text: I looked at which companies' PMs become the first PM at another startup that they join, Palantir is number two in the world.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Indicates Palantir alumni are frequently trusted to build product functions from scratch—an actionable signal for hiring.

quotes.topic_title: Why Palantir creates so many founders
quotes.text: And then I looked at which companies alumni PMs become heads of Product down later in their career, Palantir is number three in the world.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Shows longer-term leadership outcomes, reinforcing that Palantir may develop durable product leadership skills.

quotes.topic_title: Why Palantir creates so many founders
quotes.text: I actually want to start a question that I imagine every employee at Palantir constantly gets that, and I still don't think people totally have an answer in their head. What does Palantir do?
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive setup: despite elite outcomes, even insiders may struggle to articulate the company’s core, hinting at complexity or uniqueness.

quotes.topic_title: What Palantir does: outcomes via data platforms
quotes.text: So, Palantir is, the way I describe it, is they achieve outcomes for their customers very tactically.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: Frames Palantir’s positioning around concrete customer outcomes rather than abstract technology, a useful lens for product strategy and messaging.

quotes.topic_title: What Palantir does: outcomes via data platforms
quotes.text: The way they do that tends to be through a data platform.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: Connects outcomes to an enabling platform, highlighting a practical model: deliver results by standardizing the underlying data layer.

quotes.topic_title: What Palantir does: outcomes via data platforms
quotes.text: So, they have what I consider to be the world's best data platform, and I can go into what that means in a second.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A strong, memorable claim that underscores the competitive moat being the platform itself—useful for thinking about differentiation.

quotes.topic_title: What Palantir does: outcomes via data platforms
quotes.text: So, there's one that's optimized for intelligence and defense use cases that one is called Gotham. And then there's one that's more optimized for commercial use cases and that one's called Foundry.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: Illustrates a segmentation strategy: tailor the same core platform into distinct products optimized for different customer contexts.

quotes.topic_title: What Palantir does: outcomes via data platforms
quotes.text: They typically work with very large customers is the other thing. So, it's going to be Fortune 50. It's going to be governments around the world. It's going to be those kinds of customers.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A concrete go-to-market focus on the largest enterprises and governments, useful for practitioners evaluating ICP and sales motion fit.

quotes.topic_title: Culture and hiring: independent, intellectual, competitive
quotes.text: And so, I feel like what happened at some point is they raised a lot of money and they resorted to all these really interesting ways of just getting top talent out of places like Stanford and other top schools and just people who knew the founders who tended to be very interesting intellectual people. And I feel like they screened really hard for a few traits in particular. So, I would say one is very independent-minded people, people who weren't afraid to push back, who questioned the frame of everything and thought for themselves and had strong convictions.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A concrete hiring rubric: explicitly screen for independence and willingness to challenge assumptions, not just skills.

quotes.topic_title: Culture and hiring: independent, intellectual, competitive
quotes.text: The way they screened for this was interesting too. So, for the longest time, they had... Everyone does this now, I think, but at the time, it was a little bit rarer, is a founder had to interview you in order for you to receive an offer.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A practical process design: require a founder interview as a high-signal gate to preserve culture and talent bar.

quotes.topic_title: Culture and hiring: independent, intellectual, competitive
quotes.text: There was also the question of, I think it might have been Thiel who mentioned this, but he thinks that a lot of the best recruiters in the world or the companies that attract talent, they put out this distinctive bad signal and it has to turn some people off. That's the key of a good, bad signal.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A contrarian recruiting strategy: intentionally polarize to attract the exact kind of candidates you want.

quotes.topic_title: Culture and hiring: independent, intellectual, competitive
quotes.text: On my team at Palantir, one process that we followed, I could talk about this more if it's interesting, is when you started a new project, you basically had to organize what they called a murder board for it. I think this is originally an army type. So, the idea is, basically, you write up a two-page plan for the project. You invite three or four smart folks who don't know anything about the project and their job is just to tear apart your plan.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A reusable methodology for project planning: stress-test a concise plan with informed outsiders tasked to find flaws.

quotes.topic_title: Principles, murder boards, and values that exclude
quotes.text: So, the idea is, basically, you write up a two-page plan for the project. You invite three or four smart folks who don't know anything about the project and their job is just to tear apart your plan.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable planning ritual (“murder board”) for stress-testing a project plan with fresh, critical reviewers.

quotes.topic_title: Principles, murder boards, and values that exclude
quotes.text: And one section was principles that you're following for this project.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: Highlights the practice of explicitly defining project principles upfront as part of the plan, not as an afterthought.

quotes.topic_title: Principles, murder boards, and values that exclude
quotes.text: Everyone likes to move fast." It is not a good principle actually because nobody can really disagree with this reasonably.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A counterintuitive test for principles: if it’s universally agreeable, it’s too generic to guide real tradeoffs.

quotes.topic_title: Principles, murder boards, and values that exclude
quotes.text: You need something that actually a lot of people are going to go, "Why are you taking this principle? This seems wrong to me." So, you need something that people can disagree with.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A memorable heuristic for crafting strong principles: make them specific enough to provoke disagreement and clarify choices.

quotes.topic_title: Undervalued talent pools and founder training effects
quotes.text: there was a lot of talent that was a little bit outside of the tech ecosystem but could easily have been very successful within it.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: Highlights a repeatable recruiting strategy: look for high-potential candidates in adjacent ecosystems that mainstream tech underestimates.

quotes.topic_title: Undervalued talent pools and founder training effects
quotes.text: Palantir managed to get a bunch of that talent. And at the time, that was very undervalued.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A concrete example of exploiting a market inefficiency in hiring—capturing undervalued talent before others recognize it.

quotes.topic_title: Undervalued talent pools and founder training effects
quotes.text: The people who succeed the most in the Marines or the Special Forces or whatever it is, tend to be pretty smart people. They tend to have accomplished very difficult goals in very hostile environments. And it turns out that when you're starting a somewhat chaotic tech company, that's actually a very useful skill to have.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: Connects a non-obvious background (military/intelligence) to startup performance by mapping “hostile environments” to “chaotic” company-building.

quotes.topic_title: Undervalued talent pools and founder training effects
quotes.text: what is the talent that maybe is a little bit undervalued now and how do you actually draw those people to you? And I think that game is always shifting.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A durable mental model for recruiting: continuously identify undervalued talent pools and adapt your attraction strategy as the market changes.

quotes.topic_title: Undervalued talent pools and founder training effects
quotes.text: I even think it turned a lot of people who might not have become founders into good founders because of the way it works. So, I think there was a selection effect there, but there is also some training effect too, but it's unique to the way the company works.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: Introduces a useful lens for talent outcomes—separating “selection effects” from “training effects” when evaluating why alumni succeed.

quotes.topic_title: No titles philosophy and its tradeoffs
quotes.text: as soon as we have these title, you have a thing that people are competing for and then you get these very unproductive conflicts. You get people optimizing to game the system. You get Goodhart's law everywhere. So, it's like you have a metric and then people basically manage to the metrics.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A clear mental model for why formal titles can become a gamed metric that drives politics over outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: No titles philosophy and its tradeoffs
quotes.text: Rather than, let's say, improving an existing product, what you do is you start a completely new product and that has your name attached to it. And then when it comes to promotion season, you could say, "Hey, I did this new thing." And then boom, you have a new Google product, but it's maybe confusing to the end user.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A concrete example of how promotion incentives can bias teams toward launching new things instead of improving what users already rely on.

quotes.topic_title: No titles philosophy and its tradeoffs
quotes.text: titles are not going to be this memetic totem that everybody competes for. Instead, everyone is just going to have the same slightly meaningless title, which is forward deployed engineer.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A memorable articulation of the “no titles” mechanism: remove the status object to reduce internal competition.

quotes.topic_title: No titles philosophy and its tradeoffs
quotes.text: maybe the competition isn't as explicit around a specific title, but instead, what it becomes about is there's a particular exact or something and you want to gain that favor. And so, it becomes more about who can get in the inner circle of this person or whatever.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A counterintuitive tradeoff: removing titles can shift status games into informal influence and proximity to power.

quotes.topic_title: No titles philosophy and its tradeoffs
quotes.text: But if you start performing well, it's actually very easy to shift that because there is no explicit " I am the GM of this project title." And so, you always had to earn your place in the company. You always had to earn the right to work on what you were working on, and I think that was a good side effect.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: An operational benefit of minimal titles: roles stay fluid, making it easier to reassign leadership based on performance.

quotes.topic_title: Forward deployed engineers: embedded customer builders
quotes.text: So, the way this originated was, basically, you can think of it as there's two types of engineer at Palantir. So, there's one that works on the core products.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: Introduces a clear organizational model: separate core product engineers from field-embedded engineers.

quotes.topic_title: Forward deployed engineers: embedded customer builders
quotes.text: So, what that meant was you would spend maybe Monday to Thursday and you would actually go into the building where the customer worked and you would work alongside them. You would literally get a desk there.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: Concrete operating cadence for deep customer embedding that goes far beyond typical customer interviews.

quotes.topic_title: Forward deployed engineers: embedded customer builders
quotes.text: So, within the company, that function is known as business development or BD. And then PD is product development. So, it's where the product is made. And so, within BD, you had forward deployed engineers.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: Defines a structural split (BD vs PD) that explains where FDEs sit and how the org is designed to deliver outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Forward deployed engineers: embedded customer builders
quotes.text: it turns out that there's a lot of people who are technical adjacent, shall we say, who you really need in the room when you're working with these large organizations or these large companies, because translating what you're doing into language that would resonate with an executive or being able to navigate the social dynamics in a room, all these are very valuable skills.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: Counterintuitive hiring insight: “technical-adjacent” skills can be essential for success in complex enterprise environments.

quotes.topic_title: Forward deployed engineers: embedded customer builders
quotes.text: But all of that was given the title of forward deployed engineer, and it's just an engineer who works with customers.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: Memorable definition that clarifies the role’s essence and helps teams avoid overcomplicating the concept.

quotes.topic_title: Why FDEs create founders: rapid iteration loops
quotes.text: the side effect of that was, one, you learn to live and breathe the customer's problems and you learn to speak their language. And eventually, they saw you as one of them and so, you develop these really close bonds with the customers.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A practical model for earning trust and accelerating discovery by embedding deeply enough to internalize the customer’s world.

quotes.topic_title: Why FDEs create founders: rapid iteration loops
quotes.text: It would not be priced as, "Hey, you're buying data infrastructure and it's similar to Snowflake or Databricks or one of these other providers. It's much more anchored to, here is the outcome.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A clear articulation of outcome-based pricing as a differentiator versus feature/infra-based positioning.

quotes.topic_title: Why FDEs create founders: rapid iteration loops
quotes.text: But then the job of the forward deployed engineer is not just to deploy software. It is not just to sell software. It is to actually solve the problem.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: Defines the FDE role as an end-to-end problem-solving function, not a traditional engineering or sales interface.

quotes.topic_title: Why FDEs create founders: rapid iteration loops
quotes.text: But that would be the motion, is you learn about the problem. You figure out what software would best address it. You build that software. You use it to accomplish the goal. And then eventually, that gets folded into the broader product suite.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A repeatable methodology for turning bespoke deployments into scalable product capabilities.

quotes.topic_title: Why FDEs create founders: rapid iteration loops
quotes.text: So, every week, you would have a cadence where it's like Monday, you go in. You do your meetings. Monday night, you build something. Tuesday, you show it to somebody. Tuesday, you get the feedback. Tuesday night, you iterate on it. Wednesday, you show it to somebody. Wednesday night, you iterate on it. So, you get four of these, five of these cycles every single week.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A concrete operating cadence for rapid iteration loops that compress learning and delivery into days, not quarters.

quotes.topic_title: From services to platform: Foundry’s evolution
quotes.text: Not many people know about this, but you can go and sign up with a credit card right now and start using it.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: Concrete proof-point that Palantir is a real product (not just services) and is accessible enough to self-serve.

quotes.topic_title: From services to platform: Foundry’s evolution
quotes.text: So they have 80% plus margins, which is not really what you would get if you were actually a consulting company. It would be closer to 20 or 30%.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A simple diagnostic metric for distinguishing a scalable software platform from a services-heavy business.

quotes.topic_title: From services to platform: Foundry’s evolution
quotes.text: But we kept building tooling that was useful for forward deployed engineers. So we were our own first customers and at some point there was this concept of, "Wait, what if we take our internal tools and we let our customers use them?"
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A repeatable productization method: build internal tools for delivery teams, then turn them outward into customer-facing product.

quotes.topic_title: From services to platform: Foundry’s evolution
quotes.text: And then Shyam Sankar, I think he's the CTO, maybe he's the president now, he just mandated like, "Okay. Every customer deployment you have to have a customer using this within three months or whatever."
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: An operational forcing function that drives adoption and rapidly exposes usability/reliability gaps.

quotes.topic_title: From services to platform: Foundry’s evolution
quotes.text: The basic one was just data integration is massively painful inside organizations.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A clear “wedge” problem statement that can guide product focus toward a broadly generalizable pain point.

quotes.topic_title: Gotham vs Foundry: maps, graphs, and tables
quotes.text: So they both have, I would describe this almost as a pyramid where the bottom layer is data ingestion, the middle layer is data mapping, and then the top layer is anything that's user facing. So any UI component.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A clear mental model for decomposing data platforms into layers practitioners can use to evaluate or design products.

quotes.topic_title: Gotham vs Foundry: maps, graphs, and tables
quotes.text: So what is the actual difference then? I would say with Gotham, you're looking much more at workflows like that involve maps, for example.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A practical differentiator: match product/workflow design to the dominant user interface paradigm (maps vs other views).

quotes.topic_title: Gotham vs Foundry: maps, graphs, and tables
quotes.text: Another big difference is the idea of graph-based analysis.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: Highlights a core methodological split—graph workflows vs traditional analytics—that affects data modeling and UX choices.

quotes.topic_title: Gotham vs Foundry: maps, graphs, and tables
quotes.text: So it's like, "Who is everybody that Lenny called in the last week?" Imagine all the nodes fanning out from there.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A concrete example of graph queries that makes the “network” approach operational and easy to visualize.

quotes.topic_title: Gotham vs Foundry: maps, graphs, and tables
quotes.text: So Foundry is a lot more traditional in that way.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A counterweight to hype: many enterprise use cases still center on classic SQL/table workflows rather than graphs.

quotes.topic_title: Airbus case study and the Ontology breakthrough
quotes.text: So it's like the numbers are very approximate, but it's like, "Okay. We're producing 4 this month, we need to do 8 the next month, 16 the month after, and so forth, and you are going to help us do it."
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A concrete example of setting an explicit, escalating operational target that forces focus on execution rather than abstract “digital transformation.”

quotes.topic_title: Airbus case study and the Ontology breakthrough
quotes.text: So this goes back to what I was saying earlier is the mandate wasn't like, "Hey, we need to upgrade our data infrastructure. We thought you guys would be met the list of requirements." It was much more just like, "Please help us accomplish this mission. This is the big thing."
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A mission-first framing for enterprise work: anchor software efforts to a measurable business outcome, not an IT requirements checklist.

quotes.topic_title: Airbus case study and the Ontology breakthrough
quotes.text: If you could pull in those tables and join them in the right ways, and then just map them to human concepts that humans can understand, so things like a part a work order, an aircraft, et cetera, and basically build a hierarchy or mapping between them, then what you can do is, a user can just log in and say, "Okay. Aircraft 79, where is that? Okay. It's at Station 31. All right. These are the work orders, et cetera." So you've translated it into a more human-legible thing.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A practical methodology for making messy enterprise data usable: join raw tables, then map them into a human-legible object model users can navigate.

quotes.topic_title: Airbus case study and the Ontology breakthrough
quotes.text: But the overall idea of taking a bunch of tables, and then mapping them to human understandable concepts was a very powerful one.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A portable product principle: the durable innovation isn’t the one-off app, it’s the abstraction layer that turns data into concepts.

quotes.topic_title: Airbus case study and the Ontology breakthrough
quotes.text: So this actually resulted in a big piece of Foundry now, which they call Ontology.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A specific example of how forward-deployed, bespoke work can crystallize into a reusable core platform capability.

quotes.topic_title: FDE lifestyle: intense travel and in-person trust
quotes.text: The company had a very, I would say, aggressive attitude towards travel in the sense of when you join, you were basically told, "Look, you have to be okay with travel. Are you okay with that?"
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: Sets a clear hiring and culture bar: travel readiness is an explicit expectation, not an implicit perk.

quotes.topic_title: FDE lifestyle: intense travel and in-person trust
quotes.text: And the attitude, which again I think is a very founder friendly one is you need to be willing to just jump on a plane that night if that's the best thing to do for this customer and if it's going to get us to where it needs to be to win.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A practitioner rule-of-thumb for customer success: optimize for speed and winning by defaulting to in-person when it’s the highest-leverage move.

quotes.topic_title: FDE lifestyle: intense travel and in-person trust
quotes.text: So I think that's one of the takeaways for me was just being in person is so valuable when you are working with some external party, just going there for a few days and spending time with them, maybe going out for dinner.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: Highlights a repeatable trust-building playbook: short on-site visits plus informal time can accelerate external collaboration.

quotes.topic_title: FDE lifestyle: intense travel and in-person trust
quotes.text: You build so much more trust than if you're trying to close a customer over Zoom or do an engagement over Zoom. It's just the vibe is completely different.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A counterpoint to remote-first assumptions: in-person interaction can materially outperform video calls for trust and deal momentum.

quotes.topic_title: FDE lifestyle: intense travel and in-person trust
quotes.text: This obviously changed around 2020 because COVID happened, the company IPO, and so there needed to be a bit more internal controls around this.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: Notes an operational inflection point: scaling and public-company constraints can reduce the freedom that made early execution fast.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: OneSchema
quotes.text: We saw so many customers coming to us with teams of data engineers that struggled with the manual work required to clean messy spreadsheets.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Luo
quotes.context: Highlights a common, costly bottleneck—highly paid engineers spending time on low-leverage data cleanup—signaling an opportunity to automate.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: OneSchema
quotes.text: FileFeeds 2.0 allows non-technical teams to automate the process of transforming CSV and Excel files with just a simple prompt.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Luo
quotes.context: Actionable product principle: shift complex operational work from engineering to non-technical users via prompt-driven automation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: OneSchema
quotes.text: We've heard so many horror stories of outages from even just a single bad record in transactions, employee files, purchase orders, you name it.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Luo
quotes.context: Memorable reminder that data quality failures can be triggered by tiny errors, justifying proactive validation and guardrails.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: OneSchema
quotes.text: Debugging these issues is often finding a needle in a haystack.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Luo
quotes.context: A concise mental model for why reactive debugging doesn’t scale—prevention and precise error surfacing are higher leverage.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: OneSchema
quotes.text: OneSchema stops any bad data from entering your system and automatically validates your files, generating error reports with the exact issues in all bad files.
quotes.speaker: Andrew Luo
quotes.context: Concrete methodology: block bad inputs at the boundary and provide exact, actionable error reporting to reduce outages and support load.

quotes.topic_title: Founder advice: when to use FDE-like approaches
quotes.text: You probably don't need forward deployed engineers.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A contrarian default that pushes founders to avoid copying Palantir’s FDE model unless the economics truly justify it.

quotes.topic_title: Founder advice: when to use FDE-like approaches
quotes.text: But I think basically the thing there is you have to be willing to be quite almost wasteful. You have to be willing to invest a lot in finding the thing. And for that you just need a certain ticket size. So you need each customer's revenue to be probably in the billions of dollars.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A clear economic gating criterion for when heavy forward-deployed investment makes sense.

quotes.topic_title: Founder advice: when to use FDE-like approaches
quotes.text: So in a scenario like that, you might still have forward deployed engineers, but they're not going to France and spending five days a week in a factory. It's more like you'll have one person and they're looking after five different customer accounts.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A practical adaptation of FDE principles for smaller deal sizes via higher account-to-engineer ratios and lighter-touch deployments.

quotes.topic_title: Founder advice: when to use FDE-like approaches
quotes.text: My main thing here is just that you can definitely tell when you are just doing consulting and when you are closer to building a product.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A diagnostic lens for founders to distinguish bespoke services work from productizable learning.

quotes.topic_title: Founder advice: when to use FDE-like approaches
quotes.text: And I think the error that people make more often than not is they are actually too stuck on their own product vision.
quotes.speaker: Nabeel S. Qureshi
quotes.context: A warning that the more common failure mode is refusing to pivot toward the customer’s real burning problem.
